#Text=Joseph Vernon
#Text=Joseph Vernon , in character as Thurio in The Two Gentlemen of Verona , 1776 engraving
#Text=Joseph Vernon ( c.1738 – 1782 ) was an English actor and singer .
#Text=From his days as a boy soprano , he had a successful career on the London stage , interrupted only by the aftermath of an underage wedding to a colleague . [ 1 ]
#Text=Early life
#Text=Born at Coventry around 1738 , Vernon was illegitimate . [ 1 ]
#Text=He studied in London under William Savage in the choir of St Paul 's Cathedral .
#Text=As a boy he had a fine soprano voice , and on 23 February 1751 he sang at Drury Lane Theatre in Thomas Arne 's Alfred .

#Text=On 22 May he took part in Queen Mab , the pantomime by Henry Woodward ; on 20 September in the funeral procession in Romeo and Juliet ; and on 19 November in The Shepherd 's Lottery , an opera by William Boyce .
#Text=In the early part of 1754 he sang tenor parts and acted comedy at Drury Lane . , [ 2 ]
#Text=Scandal and exile in Dublin
#Text=In 1755 Vernon married Jane Poitier , a singer at Drury Lane at the Savoy Chapel .

#Text=John Wilkinson , the incumbent of the Savoy Chapel , thought that the terms of the Marriage Act 1753 , aimed at clandestine marriages , did not apply to his extra-parochial church , and continued to issue licenses and to solemnise marriages .
#Text=Among these technically irregular weddings , Vernon 's happened to be the test case taken to court by the authorities . [ 3 ]
#Text=According to Tate Wilkinson Joseph and Jane , who had been acting as " Mrs. Vernon " , were happy enough to be parted . [ 2 ]
#Text=On the other hand , the fallout of the prosecution case against the clergy of the Chapel was serious .
#Text=Wilkinson was sentenced in 1756 to 14 years transportation to British North America , and died in 1757 on the way . [ 4 ]
#Text=The curate John Grierson , who had carried out the marriage , received the same sentence : Vernon had testified at the trial , and was then hissed on stage . [ 5 ]
#Text=The unpopular Vernon moved to Dublin , where he had further success as an actor . [ 2 ]
#Text=Return to Drury Lane
#Text=Back at Drury Lane in 1762 , Vernon was given parts by David Garrick .
#Text=He combined polished singing and a natural style of acting in Shakespeare . [ 6 ]

#Text=He was also assigned some characters in comedy and farce : Colonel Bully in The Provoked Wife ; Master Stephen in Every Man in his Humour ; Sir John Loverule in The Devil to Pay , a ballad opera by Charles Coffey , and Sharp in The Lying Valet by Garrick .
#Text=According to James Boaden , Vernon 's voice in maturity was of poor quality .
#Text=Nonetheless , he continued to take singing parts in opera and interludes . [ 7 ]
#Text=The song in Act III of The School for Scandal was written by Thomas Linley for him . [ 2 ]
#Text=He took the title role in Selima and Azor , Linley 's first opera . [ 1 ]
#Text=Last years
#Text=Vernon 's last performances were Artabanes in Artaxerxes , First Bacchanal in Comus , and Truemore in The Lord of the Manor by Jackson of Exeter , 1780 .
#Text=Until 6 October 1781 he appeared in these and his older parts .
#Text=He died on 19 March 1782 at Lambeth , and the administration of his effects was granted to Margaret Vernon , his widow . [ 2 ]
#Text=Works
#Text=Vernon compiled around 1782
#Text=The New London and Country Songster , or a Banquet of Vocal Music .
#Text=He composed songs and ballads , including New Songs in the Pantomime of the Witches , the epilogue in Twelfth Night , and a song in the Two Gentlemen of Verona . [ 2 ]
